title: How your muscular system works - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the body's weight does skeletal muscle make up?
What is the main difference between fast-twitch and slow-twitch muscle fibers?

options.label: A
options.text: Fast-twitch fibers react slowly, while slow-twitch fibers react quickly.

options.label: B
options.text: Fast-twitch fibers react quickly but tire easily, while slow-twitch fibers react slowly but can work for longer periods.

options.label: C
options.text: Fast-twitch fibers are used for endurance, while slow-twitch fibers are used for strength.

options.label: D
options.text: Fast-twitch fibers are used for strength, while slow-twitch fibers are used for endurance.

options.label: A
options.text: To control the movement of skeletal muscles.

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate the heart rate and blood pressure.

options.label: C
options.text: To manage the body's temperature.

options.label: D
options.text: To control the movement of cardiac and smooth muscles.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Water.

options.label: D

title: The strange case of the cyclops sheep - Tien Nguyen

multiple-choice.question: What was the initial hypothesis of the scientists investigating the cyclops sheep?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The sheep were eating poisonous plants that caused birth defects.

options.label: C
options.text: The sheep were experiencing a genetic mutation.

options.label: D
options.text: The sheep were being affected by a disease.

options.label: B
options.text: Hedgehog Gene

options.label: C
options.text: Smoothened Protein

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It tells cells to release a hedgehog protein that signals smoothened.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to genetic mutations.

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: The discovery of a new treatment for Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome.

options.label: C
options.text: The approval of two new skin cancer medicines.

options.label: D
options.text: The creation of a new genetic mutation.

title: A brief history of banned numbers - Alessandra King

multiple-choice.question: What was the discovery of irrational numbers that led to the exile of Pythagoras' follower, Hippasus?

options.label: A
options.text: They were found to be useful for solving complex mathematical equations.

options.label: B
options.text: They were discovered to be a threat to the Pythagorean's notion of a perfect universe.

options.label: C
options.text: They were found to be a way to describe the motion of celestial bodies.

options.label: D
options.text: They were discovered to be a way to represent negative numbers.

multiple-choice.question: What was the reason for the ban on the use of Hindu-Arabic numerals in Florence in the 13th century?

options.label: A
options.text: They were considered too difficult to use for merchants and bankers.

options.label: B
options.text: They were considered easier to forge or alter than Roman numerals.

options.label: C
options.text: They were considered too complex for record keeping.

options.label: D
options.text: They were considered too time-consuming to use.

multiple-choice.question: Why were negative numbers dismissed as absurd well into the 19th century?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they were difficult to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they were considered to be a threat to the concept of zero.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they were not seen as having any practical application.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they were not considered to be a part of the Pythagorean's notion of a perfect universe.

multiple-choice.question: What is the idea that some numbers may be considered illegal because of the information they carry?

options.label: A
options.text: The concept of zero.

options.label: B
options.text: The idea of negative numbers.

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that numbers can be used to represent protected information.

options.label: D
options.text: The concept of irrational numbers.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the idea of illegal numbers gather attention in 2001?

options.label: A
options.text: Because a large prime number was discovered that could be used to decrypt DVDs.

options.label: B
options.text: Because a new mathematical equation was discovered that could be used to represent protected information.

options.label: C
options.text: Because a new way of representing numbers was discovered that could be used to represent protected information.

options.label: D
options.text: Because a new way of using numbers was discovered that could be used to represent protected information.

title: Are you a body with a mind or a mind with a body? - Maryam Alimardani

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what happens when you experience the rubber hand illusion?

options.label: A
options.text: You start to feel a sense of detachment from your body.

options.label: B
options.text: You start to feel like the dummy hand is not yours.

options.label: C
options.text: You start to feel like the dummy hand is yours, and you flinch when it's threatened with a knife.

options.label: D
options.text: You start to feel a sense of confusion about your identity.

multiple-choice.question: According to Ren√© Descartes, what is the ultimate proof of our existence?

options.label: A
options.text: The fact that our bodies can move and experience sensations.

options.label: B
options.text: The fact that our minds and thoughts exist even if our physical sensations are just a hallucinatory dream.

options.label: C
options.text: The fact that we can perceive the world around us through our senses.

options.label: D
options.text: The fact that we can communicate with others through language.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one possible solution to the problem of how a non-physical mind can interact with the physical body?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that the mind has no interaction with the body, and that our experiences are just an illusion.

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that God moves our bodies when we think about doing something.

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that the material world is an illusion, existing only as mental perceptions.

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that our bodies are deeply integrated with the activity in our brains to form what we call consciousness.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the relationship between our bodies and our subjective consciousness?

options.label: A
options.text: Our bodies and subjective consciousness are separate entities that can exist independently of each other.

options.label: B
options.text: Our bodies and subjective consciousness are deeply integrated and inseparable from each other.

options.label: C
options.text: Our bodies are just a temporary shell for our non-physical consciousness.

options.label: D
options.text: Our subjective consciousness is just a product of our physical bodies.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one possible future technology that could challenge our understanding of the relationship between the mind and the body?

options.label: A
options.text: Neural prosthetics that can extend our sense of self to new wearable devices.

options.label: B
options.text: Mind uploading, which involves transferring a human consciousness into a computer.

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither A nor B.

title: The left brain vs. right brain myth - Elizabeth Waters

multiple-choice.question: What is the prevailing idea about the brain's left and right sides, and what does it get wrong?

options.label: A
options.text: The left side controls creativity and the right side controls logic, but this is supported by scientific evidence.

options.label: B
options.text: The left side controls logic and the right side controls creativity, but this is a myth unsupported by scientific evidence.

options.label: C
options.text: The left side controls movement and the right side controls sight.

options.label: D
options.text: The left side controls vision and the right side controls movement.

multiple-choice.question: Why do scientists think that the brain's left and right sides control different body functions, such as movement and sight?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the left and right sides of the brain are physically separated by a barrier.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the left and right sides of the brain control different body functions, such as movement and sight.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the brain's structure has a right and a left side, which is most apparent with the outer layer, or the cortex.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the brain's internal regions, like the striatum, hypothalamus, thalamus, and brain stem, are organized with left and right sides.

multiple-choice.question: What is one theory as to why animals developed the brain's left-right structure, which gives the survival advantage of quicker reflexes?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it allows for more complex nervous systems.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it allows for faster movement.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it allows for quicker reflexes, such as escaping to the right when seeing a predator coming from the left side.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it allows for better vision.

multiple-choice.question: What did researchers Broca and Wernicke find in patients who had problems communicating due to injuries, and what did they suggest as a result?

options.label: A
options.text: They found that language is controlled by the right side of the brain, and suggested that damage to the left temporal lobes was the cause.

options.label: B
options.text: They found that language is controlled by the left side of the brain, and suggested that damage to the left temporal lobes was the cause.

options.label: C
options.text: They found that language is controlled by the right side of the brain, and suggested that damage to the right temporal lobes was the cause.

options.label: D
options.text: They found that language is controlled by the left side of the brain, but suggested that damage to the right temporal lobes was the cause.

multiple-choice.question: What is one example of how the idea of a left-right split between logic and creativity does not hold up well, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Solving complex math problems requires only logic and not creativity.

options.label: B
options.text: Many vibrant works of art have intricate logical frameworks, which require both creativity and logic.

options.label: C
options.text: Solving complex math problems requires only creativity and not logic.

options.label: D
options.text: Many vibrant works of art have no logical frameworks, which require only creativity.

title: How to squeeze electricity out of crystals - Ashwini Bharathula

multiple-choice.question: What type of materials can turn mechanical stress into electricity and vice versa?

options.label: B
options.text: Piezoelectric materials

options.label: C
options.text: Conductive materials

options.label: D
options.text: Insulating materials

options.label: A
options.text: In sonar instruments used to detect German submarines during World War I

options.label: B
options.text: In medical imaging

options.label: C
options.text: In ink jet printers

options.label: D
options.text: In smartwatches

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why some crystalline materials are piezoelectric?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have a center of symmetry

options.label: B
options.text: Because they lack a center of symmetry

options.label: C
options.text: Because they have a net separation of charge

options.label: D
options.text: Because they have a net positive charge

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The voltage generated decreases

options.label: C
options.text: The voltage generated switches, making current flow the other way

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To create a new type of battery

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What are creative constraints?

options.label: B
options.text: Factors that drive discovery and invention

options.label: C
options.text: The tools and techniques available for a project

options.label: D
options.text: The laws of physics that govern a project

options.label: A
options.text: They allow scientists to work without boundaries

options.label: B
options.text: They guide experimental design and help scientists understand the limits of their knowledge

options.label: C
options.text: They are a necessary evil for scientists to follow

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: To treat symptoms immediately and contain beta-agonists

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Scarring of the airways and reduced oxygen delivery

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Poverty and lack of access to medical care

options.label: C
options.text: Genetics and family history

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

title: How do nuclear power plants work? - M. V. Ramana and Sajan Saini

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the first nuclear reactor built in Chicago?

options.label: A
options.text: It failed to produce energy.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It led to a nuclear meltdown.

options.label: D
options.text: It was shut down due to public opposition.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge for a nuclear reactor to safely contain?

options.label: A
options.text: Radioactive fission products.

options.label: B
options.text: The chain reaction of neutrons.

options.label: C
options.text: The concentration of U-235.

options.label: D
options.text: The heat generated by the reactor.

multiple-choice.question: Why is the concentration of U-235 enriched in modern reactors?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the rate of fission.

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce the risk of a nuclear meltdown.

options.label: C
options.text: To compensate for the kinetic energy of neutrons.

options.label: D
options.text: To create an explosive chain reaction.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a coolant in a nuclear reactor?

options.label: A
options.text: To slow down neutrons.

options.label: B
options.text: To capture excess neutrons.

options.label: C
options.text: To capture heat generated by the reactor.

options.label: D
options.text: To prevent a nuclear meltdown.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main concern with storing spent nuclear fuel?

options.label: A
options.text: Radioactivity.

options.label: B
options.text: Environmental impact.

options.label: C
options.text: Security risk of plutonium being mined for bombs.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

options.label: C
options.text: Competition with other species for food and resources

options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the digestive system of sloths, particularly three-toed sloths?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a single-chambered stomach

options.label: B
options.text: They have a multi-chambered stomach that takes up a third of their body

options.label: C
options.text: They have a short digestive tract

options.label: D
options.text: They have a specialized gut that allows them to extract nutrients from leaves quickly

multiple-choice.question: How often do sloths typically descend from the canopy to the ground?

options.label: A
options.text: Daily

options.label: B
options.text: Weekly

options.label: C
options.text: Monthly

options.label: D
options.text: Seasonally

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the physical adaptations that allows sloths to conserve energy and minimize their metabolic rate?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a high muscle mass

options.label: B
options.text: They have a low body temperature

options.label: C
options.text: They have a low body temperature that can fluctuates by about five degrees Celsius

options.label: D
options.text: They have a high metabolic rate
